The 'Eteri Expiration Date': Inside ROC's Quad Squad

22/02/2022

Neve Iredale takes a look at the suspicious techniques of the Russian figure skating team.

Image by Wikimedia Commons

By Neve Iredale

Kamila Valievaâ€™s doping scandal has garnered sour attention for Olympic figure skating, and further worsened Russiaâ€™s sporting reputation. The 15-year-old Valieva is coached by the infamous Eteri Tutberidze, leader of the â€˜Quad Squadâ€™.

A â€˜quadâ€™, in figure skating terms, is a jump with four full rotations. The first female to land a quad in an international competition was 14-year-old Miki Ando in 2002, followed by aÂ  15-year gap until Alexandra Trusova (aged 13 at the time) became the second-ever female to land a ratified quad in 2018. The quadruple jump has thus been stuff of legend, only ever associated with male skating. Up to 2018, the triple axel was the most coveted skill in womenâ€™s skating at the Olympic games, that is, until Trusova shook up the sport, perhaps forever.

Valieva and Trusova are both â€˜Eteriâ€™s girlsâ€™, coached by Eteri Tutberidze at the Samba school in Moscow. Tutberidzeâ€™s monopoly on Russian skating success began in 2014 with 15 year old skating prodigy Yulia Lipnitskaya taking home a stunningly golden victory for the team, but this was only the beginning. Since the Sochi games, Tutberidze has churned out child stars like no other, with her girls expected to make a clean sweep at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics.

The prime-time to master a quad jump has proven to be around 11-13 in young girls, when body mass is at a substantial low but muscle mass has developed enough to support the height of the jumps required to achieve four rotations. This is simply not sustainable, however, when puberty hits and the body changes; to continue to pursue the quad jumps so voraciously is immeasurably damaging not only to physical health, but also to the mental resilience of the vulnerable girls. Eteri Tutberidze is the pioneer of this method, and has received further allegations that she prescribes her skaters hormone blockers, to decelerate natural ageing and keep her girls in prepubescent condition.

The â€˜Quad Revolutionâ€™ has advanced at breakneck speed, with Russia at its spearhead. Since Trusova, 17 more female skaters have landed ratified quads in competition, 13 more have at least attempted them in competition or successfully landed them in training with video evidence: of these 30, 21 are Russian, and 25 are under 18. By the end of 2019, eight women had landed quads in competition, and six of them were coached by Eteri Tutberidze, the youngest being only 11-years-old. The Russian coach began her quest for the coveted quad around 2010-2011, but of course didnâ€™t succeed until 2018, with her success being largely attributed to her selection of tiny skaters with natural talent. In light of the recent doping scandal, however, doubt has been cast as to whether the 15-year-gap in between the first quad and Tutberidzeâ€™s â€˜Quad Revolutionâ€™ is plausible. That is, whether Valievaâ€™s teammates, Trusova and Shcherbakova, can attribute their success to performance enhancing drugs.

Having understood the difficulty of mastering the quad, the toll it takes and whatâ€™s at stake, the â€˜Eteri expiration dateâ€™ becomes easier to comprehend: an overtly suspicious term used in the industry for the rate at which Eteri Tutberidze churns out skating sensations, only to discard them when they turn 17. From this age, hormone blockers become less effective and injuries from overtraining become too serious to ignore. Yulia Lipnitskaya, the first of â€˜Eteriâ€™s girlsâ€™, retired at 17 citing significant knee and hip problems, as well as anorexia. The short careers of Eteriâ€™s girls are atypical of figure skating, with most non-russian skaters competing to a high level throughout their 20s.

The â€˜ladiesâ€™ Olympic competition took place this past Thursday, and could not be any more telling of Tutberidzeâ€™s cruel mentorship. In fourth place was Kamila Valieva, the 15-year-old who made headlines for her positive drug test. Valieva was ultimately able to continue competing in the games because of her age, and because the substances were â€˜non-specificâ€™, meaning that they are likely to be added to a prohibited list in future but made for a relatively easy appeal process. The IOC did however stipulate that there would not be a medal ceremony if the athlete finished in the podium places. Valieva went on to complete an uncharacteristically botched routine, stepping out or failing most of her jumps. Tears and heartache followed her performance.

Alexandra Trusova, or â€˜Sashaâ€™, as sheâ€™s more fondly known, became the first female to land five quads in one routine. Although she had a couple of wobbles, the routine was clean. The 17-year-old quad machine took silver, but received the news in tears, as she exclaimed â€˜everyone has gold but meâ€™ and â€˜Iâ€™m never stepping on the ice againâ€™. While the average viewer would interpret this outburst as ungrateful or immature, itâ€™s really the culmination of a decadeâ€™s worth of emotional turmoil. From the beginning of Trusovaâ€™s career, Eteri Tutberidze has assured the athlete that quads were everything, that to break records and cleanly land an inhuman amount of big jumps would be the surest way to secure the gold medal. In turn, Trusova dedicated her career to the mastery of quadruple jumps, almost entirely ignoring the artistic element of figure skating. This would prove to be an error, as she would ultimately lose to a routine that combined big jumps with soft music and graceful lines. This stood in contrast to Trusovaâ€™s program, accompanied by a cover of The Stooges and packed with massive jumps. Although a failed quad can easily be worth more technical points than a successful triple, artistic expression remains highly important, and Trusovaâ€™s routine missed the mark in this regard. Trusova can be heard in clips shouting â€˜you knew everythingâ€™ at her coach, Tutberidze.

Taking home gold was Anna Shcherbakova, long-time member of the Quad Squad and team Tutberidze. The long time member of team Tutberidze put on a beautiful show, with two quads in her free-skate but much more intricate choreography than her teammate Trusova. When all was said and done, however, Scherbakova was left to celebrate her win alone as her compatriots were being consoled. The image is deeply sad - sat only with the company of her cuddly teddy bear that doubles as a tissue dispenser. When asked about her win, Anna said she felt â€˜emptyâ€™.

Emotions on the podium were ultimately solemn, likely because all three girls are fully aware of the â€˜Eteri expiration dateâ€™; this was their one and only Olympics. Many parallels can be drawn between the pressure of elite gymnastics and figure skating, especially with regard to coaching and discipline. However, it would be highly unusual not to see the gymnastics gold medalist return for the next Olympics. This is not unusual for Russian figure skating, and all signs point towards Anna Shcherbakova retiring before the next Winter Games.
